para.paratext: One witness is generally enough to establish a fact,[1] but the jury may consider the number of witnesses as going to weight of the evidence.[2] The preponderance, however, is not necessarily with the greater number.[3] Thus, most times, the number of witnesses is merely a factor that may affect the weight of the evidence as a whole.
In certain types of cases, more than one witness may be required. Georgia law provides:

The testimony of a single witness is generally sufficient to establish a fact. However, in certain cases, including prosecutions for treason, prosecutions for perjury, and felony cases where the only witness is an accomplice, the testimony of a single witness is not sufficient. Nevertheless, corroborating circumstances may dispense with the necessity for the testimony of a second witness, except in prosecutions for treason.[4]

Also, in criminal cases, an informant who assists and cooperates with a law enforcement agency in gathering evidence against the defendant is not an accomplice, and thus, his testimony alone will be sufficient.[5]

Even when an accomplice offers the testimony, slight evidence of corroboration connecting the defendant to the crime satisfies the corroboration requirement, and that evidence may be entirely circumstantial.[6] The testimony of one accomplice may also be used to corroborate that of another.[7] However, the corroborating evidence must be independent of the accomplice testimony and must directly connect the defendant with the crime or otherwise support the inference that he is guilty.[8] The trier of fact will decide whether the corroborating evidence is sufficient to convict.[9]
See also Fields v. Yellow Cab Co. of Atlanta, 80 Ga. App. 569, 56 S.E.2d 845 (1949).
State v. Pickens, 330 Ga. App. 862, 769, 769 S.E.2d 594, 315 Ed. Law Rep. 1099 (2015).

See, e.g., Fain v. State, 211 Ga. App. 399, 439 S.E.2d 64 (1993), holding that no corroborating testimony was necessary for conviction of drug possession where there was sufficient corroborating physical evidence, i.e., drugs found in his home.

Slight evidence of corroboration connecting defendant with crime satisfies requirements of O.C.G.A. § 24-14-8 and that evidence may be entirely circumstantial. Parkerson v. State, 265 Ga. 438, 457 S.E.2d 667 (1995).
Moss v. State, 278 Ga. App. 362, 629 S.E.2d 5 (2006).

Emory v. State, 301 Ga. App. 771, 774, 688 S.E.2d 682 (2009): “It is not required that the corroboration of the testimony given by an accomplice shall of itself be sufficient to warrant a verdict of guilty, or that the testimony of the accomplice be corroborated in every particular. The amount of corroborative extraneous evidence necessary to connect the accused with the commission of the offense lies peculiarly within the province of the fact finder.”
See also Daniels v. State, 306 Ga. App. 577, 581, 703 S.E.2d 41 (2010); Benbow v. State, 288 Ga. 192, 194–95, 702 S.E.2d 180 (2010).

“[E]vidence of the defendant's conduct before and after the crime was committed may give rise to an inference that he participated in the crime.” Jones v. State, 302 Ga. App. 147, 149, 690 S.E.2d 460 (2010).

“While it is true that a felony conviction cannot be sustained based only on the uncorroborated testimony of one accomplice …, where an additional accomplice provides testimony to corroborate that of the first accomplice, the evidence can suffice to sustain the conviction.” Martinez v. State, 306 Ga. App. 512, 520, 702 S.E.2d 747 (2010) (quoting Gallimore v. State, 264 Ga. App. 629, 630, 591 S.E.2d 485 (2003)).
